metadata.notes: Delivered at St. John’s Church, Salisbury, CT; September 15, 1996.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher avoids moralistic 'musts' regarding behavior, but maintains a firm dogmatic boundary regarding what constitutes 'true' preaching versus 'false' preaching.
quotes: With all due respect, that is not what they are doing.
Disbelief was all the rage among the clergy... and we have not recovered.

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent appears at the end, offering the Word as a source of love and security without creating a dependency on the preacher himself.
quotes: Receive from him the love from which we shall never be separated.

adult.analysis: The preacher uses historical context, literary references (Churchill, Wilder), and linguistic analysis to build a case. He treats the listener as a thinking subject capable of following a theological argument.
quotes: We cannot understand even the most basic things... if we do not grasp this fundamental Biblical assertion.
The dictionary gives us a definition of preaching that has nothing to do with the real thing.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher admits to his own 'fear and trembling,' but this is presented as an authentic professional awe rather than a neurotic need to please or a fear of punishment.
quotes: I was duly dashed for a while but not for too long.
If your knees did not tremble... you were not fit to preach.

free_child_FC.analysis: There is a sense of 'delicious irony' and intellectual excitement, though the tone remains largely formal and reverent.
quotes: There is delicious irony in that; the last shall be first.
I am amused to remember his own arrogance.

ego_positions_scan.dominant_ego_position: Adult with a strong Nurturing Parent finish.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher primarily engages in information sharing and reality testing. He invites the congregation to look at history and scripture objectively before moving to a spiritual conclusion.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: There is a slight psychological 'Parent -> Child' message regarding the 'correct' way to view the Bible, subtly shaming 'skeptical' mainline clergy.
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The risk is a subtle 'Us vs. Them' (Orthodox vs. Skeptic) which can invite the congregation into a 'Critical Parent' stance toward other churches.

detected_games.name: Ain't It Awful

formula_g_analysis.con: The world/church is losing its way.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's nostalgia for 'the good old days' of Churchill or King.
formula_g_analysis.switch: None—the preacher stays in a hopeful Adult/NP role.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: A sense of being the 'faithful remnant' who still understands the Truth.

evidence_quotes: As our American culture drifts farther and farther away... it is going to become more and more important for those of us who are Christians.

games_analysis.absence_of_games_analysis: The sermon is remarkably game-free because the preacher explicitly rejects the role of 'Rescuer' or 'Hero,' insisting that the power lies in the 'Word' and not his own performance.

preacher_roles.rescuer: Low. He explicitly denies his ability to save, calling himself a 'flawed and sinful' vessel.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Low. Only briefly directed at 'skeptical' clergy who stopped preaching.
preacher_roles.victim: Low. He mentions 'weakness and fear' but as a theological necessity, not a bid for pity.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is invited to be 'Disciples' (Adults) rather than Victims of the world or the preacher's ego.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: The sermon offers an escape by pointing to an external 'Word' that empowers both preacher and listener equally.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: This sermon is psychologically robust and largely avoids manipulative games. By utilizing an Adult-to-Adult transaction, the preacher respects the listener's autonomy. He successfully navigates the 'Drama Triangle' by refusing the Rescuer role, instead positioning himself as a fellow-traveler under the authority of the 'Word.' The use of 'Critical Parent' is limited to defining theological boundaries rather than coercing behavior, which fosters a healthy environment for spiritual growth.
strengths: High transparency regarding the preacher's own limitations.
Strong Adult ego presence that encourages intellectual engagement.
areas_for_improvement: Slight tendency toward 'Ain't it Awful' regarding modern culture.
The distinction between 'preaching' and 'instruction' could be perceived as exclusionary (Critical Parent).
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Continue to emphasize the 'shared' experience of the Word to prevent the congregation from slipping into a dependent 'Adapted Child' role.
